pros: UCAS is a great place to work. They offer flexible working options, such as 9 day fortnight, 4 day week, etc. Six weeks annual leave as standard, plus the option to purchase more. Also, depending on your role, they can usually offer either work from home or hybrid working contracts.

Salaries could potentially be a bit better, but UCAS is a charity and there are plenty of benefits that counter this, including 30 days holiday.

review_title: Excellent company, enjoyed going to work.
pros: UCAS is a very good company. They are fussy hirers (In a good way) which meant that almost every employee was friendly and ambitious! of course, there some that are the exception ;) but no place is truly perfect, however UCAS came close.  I joined as a web developer and was welcome by the team, who had no ego! (bonus!) and was allowed/invited to share my thoughts on current procedures and offer advice (my thoughts) on how it could be improved, they listened and debated professionally (instead of stating your new, you have no right etc... we know those places) and my changes were designed. They offer good career progression and training! my line manager allowed me to shadow a certain section of the business every Friday to build up my skill set in that area, which he didn't have to do. He was also going to pay a good sum of money to get me formally qualified. I could continue writing, but you'd be reading for a good while! So, I'll sum it up. UCAS is a friendly company, who is willing to train, offer it's staff progression and is a place were going to work everyday is a joy. Note, I had to leave for unforeseen reasons.
cons: Windows are locked shut for safety reasons and don't open!

review_title: You'll only find politics, no accountability and poor decision making here
pros: The teams contain good natured people who are good to work with
cons:
Those good natured people in teams are massively taken advantage of by management.

The company has no idea of what it wants to be or do.

All managers are concerned about is building their own little empires and playing politics - no concern for looking after people or doing anything useful for students/universities/companies - or any clients for that matter. Projects become money pits with poor reasons for existence (other than to promote/advertise a manager's position) delivering no return on investment.

All the empire building paves ways for a culture of passive aggression, politics and taking advantage of people for personal gain. That culture is used to completely justify taking advantage of and abusing employees.

The convoluted processes and multiple management layers seem to obfuscate any form of sensible decision making. Indeed, they seem to act as a mechanism of removing all accountability for dreadful decisions or abusing employees.

job_title: Information Services Department in Cheltenham, England
pros: On site parking, nice building, restaurant, above average pay for some jobs, Personal Performance Plan and Personal Performance Review for pay rises - some people got 3% last year because they did well.  On the PPP you can specify training etc.  Lots of charity work and groups to join and represent e.g. The Green Team looking at how to make UCAS greener.
cons:
Poor management structure, lots of disagreeing between them that creates problems for departments and filters further down to teams and people.
The place restructures every year and many redundancies have occurred in the last 3 years.  This has created an environment of many consultants working there and a negative atmosphere, due to many people worrying about losing their jobs.
A tough recruitment process as it is computerised.  If you don't get 100% in a test specified for a job role but did well at everything else, then you won't be considered.  They are not people orientated in their recruitment process.

pros: Expert co-workers with sector knowledge
cons: The new CEO has taken a year to replace almost the entire Executive team and now is firmly in control of the organization.  Unfortunately she has no experience in higher education and it shows. So there is now a strategy based on cost reduction (constant renegotiation of existing suppler contracts),  shutting down any scheme that is loss making and the introduction of expensive consultants and ex colleagues  to support her goals. Meanwhile the dinosaur that is the new Admissions Platform continues to lurch forward with missed milestones and poor quality with little improvement over the existing legacy applications.

review_title: Not a great culture for developers
pros:
Short contractual working day/week of 7 hours/35 hours.

You get the week of Christmas as free holiday including the period between Christmas and new year.

Ample free parking in the racecourse when you're in the office.
cons:
Depending on the team you're often expected to work more hours than contracted.

You're often expected to give up your lunch breaks to partake in endless soul sapping meetings.

Bullying is commonplace in the office and managers don't seem to want or be able to stop it.

On more than one occasion a particular senior manager tried to start fights with other colleagues on social outings over minor transgressions. Due to their position and camaraderie with other senior managers nothing was ever done about it.

Some managers force methods of working on developers that in the development world is often seen as a personal preference. Test Driven Development (TDD) for example. I was told - in more words - that I would be fired if I didn't follow it 100% of the time by one particularly bossy manager.

When I was there senior managers spoke in a weird business abstracted language which made it impossible for non-senior managers to know what on earth they were saying. I believe it was a political control tactic. It made it impossible to get a clear answer out of them.

When I was there they had about 8 development teams, all working on different parts of the same system. They ran into the same problem where the sheer number of people added a huge communication overhead to everything - effectively slowing development to a crawl. To this day I still don't understand how they took over 2 years to barely create a working system using so many teams.

Some senior developers were very abrasive and hard to work with. One particular individual would often loudly exclaim how suggestions were a foul and rude term, e.g.explicit synonym for poo. When the same tactic was sent his way he would loudly yell - in an open plan office filled with people - that the critiquer should "(explicit synonym for intercourse) off" or similar.

On a similar note to abrasive senior developers, most developers and architects were also very hard to work with. The culture of communication in meetings was to talk over people, not listen. In my near two years there I could count on one hand the number of times someone stopped and tried to genuinely understand what the other person was saying.

pros: SCRUM at scale, mostly good teams of people
cons: "Manager's estimate" led delivery structure means the great Tech-led development culture started in 2015 has long ago descended into a "we'll fix it tomorrow" delivery culture.  Pretty much everyone with any real knowledge of the estate has long since left for better opportunities.
